title: Will Apple's end-of-day market capitalization exceed $1 trillion before 1 January 2018?
preds: In order for Apple to reach a market capitalization of $1 trillion by January 1, 2018, its value would have to increase by about 11 percent in the next two weeks. An increase of that magnitude will only occur if there is a significant news event that triggers it, the most likely of which would be a higher than expected earnings report. Given that Apple does not report earnings again until January 30, it seems highly unlikely that the company will reach a market cap of $1 trillion by the first of next year.

While AAPL is up ~52% YTD and has a market cap as of 11/9/17 of $901 billion (per Bloomberg) the likelihood that it reaches $1 trillion in market cap by Jan 1 2018 is low in my opinion. That market cap would imply a stock price of $194.77 if no additional equity shares are issued (currently there are approximately 5,134,312,000 shares outstanding per Bloomberg) which is 10.85% higher than it's current price of $175.78.

Apple will not release earnings again before January 1, 2018.  Apple shares have climbed almost 50 percent this year on expectations for the iPhone X.  Any delays, issues, or poor reviews of the iPhone X will prevent Apple from reaching 1 trillion.  Apple has predicted records sales of $84 billion for Q4 and the stock gained nearly 4% on rollout.  The stock price would need to get to nearly $200. Apple gains about $25 in stock price every six weeks (currently at $174, 8 weeks out)

Since the first iPhone in January 2007, Apple's stock has surged almost 1,300 percent, compared to the S&P 500's 83-percent increase. Including dividends, Apple's total return has been about 1,400 percent. (tmsnrt.rs/2z5YNB0)

A lot will be determined by the November 2nd earnings report. After today's pop they're at $842B and a P/E 18.55. A combination of a great earnings report/Q4 outlook, with overall high sentiment of the tech sector at large, and any news of corporate tax changes, could be enough to get to $1T...still a lot would have to go perfect, more likely things go okay or something goes bad. 
If I remember I'll updated after Q3 report.
Unfortunately no.  Apple has two things going against it; disappointing Apple 8 launch (vs expectations) and the likely drop in the overall stock market.

Product line weakness:  there's a significant design flaw in the Apple Watch and the new iphone is too expensive for too little improvement.

stock price would have to be $193 to reach a trillion in valuation.  AAPL has not seen an upward slope in the 4th quarter that would suggest it could happen in 2017.  Also, no groundbreaking product is expected, and holiday sales volumes are credited in Q1 the following year.  On a macro level, a cycle of recession is anticipated.
The value is headed in the wrong direction!
Time is running out for this sort of big move and the stock seems to have slid backwards over the past couple weeks. It is not impossible, but it seems highly improbable at this stage of the game.

$174.183B up from Friday's post-iPhone X announcement closing of $159.88/share is a bridge too far.  I'll stipulate that investors (including this forecaster) place great faith in AAPL, but a 21% increase from here would be irrational in the time remaining.  After all, the big announcement was a $999 phone.  A segment of the iPhone consumer base was just priced out of an upgrade.  How large that segment may be is unknown.

The announcement of their new apple products (including iphone) did not increase their share value as it did in the previous years after an announcement. Apple's new products were met with mixed results which leads me to believe the public is unsure and thus, Apple's chance of becoming a trillion dollar company by January 1st 2018 is no longer feasible.

Based on historic sales of the apple products in the past in conjunction with the new standard of leasing phones from carries makes it to where anyone can buy a product. Major corporations primarily boast about units sold which drives demand for share ownership. The theoretical success of the new idevices that will be announced this coming week will dictate the overall value of the company and to meet this forecast the shares simply need to jump to $190.94 (currently at $160.86). I still give this a low probability rate because there's speculation that the iphone will have OLED technology which is in currently in short supply due to the overall demand for the technology.
Too early, unless the iPhone8 really takes off.

Decreasing probability since we are below monthly pace required.
I'll increase if part of corporate tax reform announced in the next few weeks includes one-time repatriation holiday:
https://www.cnbc.com/2017/07/13/companies-have-big-plans-foroverseas-cash--if-tax-reform-ever-happens.html

The new iphone 8 could be a flop and according to a new survey from investment firm Piper Jaffray it shows iPhone users aren't any more excited for this release than they were for the iPhone 7. Only 16% of those surveyed say they are planning to upgrade to the iPhone 8. So if this is true then this would depress Apple's stock and push it further from the $1 trillion cap. So I will project that it is almost certainly not going to exceed $1 trillion before the new year. Plus Apple's cap is still quite a distance away from reaching the trillion dollar mark.
May have been overly certain on this.

Apple would have to reach about $193.6 per share at current shares outstanding. One standard deviation from 164 using historical volatility at 22.5% and with 80 trading days left, there's a 7.73% chance that AAPL's share price will cross that threshold. This assumes today's price as the mean, which is unrealistic given it's a 52 week high. On the other hand, PE ratio seems healthy in comparison to other tech companies. Per CNN 23 analysts recommend buying, others 13 hold or outperform the market and only 1 sell. http://money.cnn.com/quote/forecast/forecast.html?symb=aapl
Updating for the passage of time.

numbers still indicate room to buy:
(1000/834)^(12/4)=1.72, i.e. that would mean an annualized return of 72% for Apple Stock. I consider this to be virtually impossible.

The psychological barrier of the $1tn market cap will be incredibly hard to overcome without breakout sales of the iPhone 8 or a new product release. Breaking $1tn would require a 22.7% move in the stock, which has happened in 13.5% of 4 month periods over the past 5 years, but I believe that the $1tn barrier in addition to recent large run ups in the stock and the overall market bring down the probability a significant amount.
Revising downward as the rate a growth seems much too slow to reach 1 trillion by the end of the year.
The market was down today, including Apple's market capitalization.  However, if it's at $833b by 9/1, the rate of increase will have been sufficient--if continued--to achieve $1T by Jan 1.
Retail investors are back thus I am increasing my prediction by 1% to 3%.
It has run up too much this the first half of the year
I see this happening after or during March

AAPL is up (current price) roughly 10.7% since my first forecast, and hit an all-time high earlier this week ($161.83). It has held up reasonably well to increasingly loud expressions of tension on the Korean Peninsula, and is trading at less than 18 times earnings. And I still cut my forecast by 50%. My reasoning? Things aren't going to get any calmer in Washington over the next four months. I suspect that the broader market will have trouble maintaining bullish momentum, which would make AAPL a prime target for profit-taking.
At current share price, implied volatility suggests it's quite unlikely
the first full quarterly earnings reflecting Iphone 8 doesn't occur until late January 18'.  One should allow for upside anticipatory trading by the army of enthusiasts.

This stock continues to do well, but the chances are highly unlikely to appreicate that much in less than 6 months. I am using 10% vol on this stocks, more or less in line with the VIX. A 1.7% dividend, in line with their most recent level. If I use 10% expected annualized return there is essentially 0% chance...15% expected annualized return yields a 1% chance...20% expected annualized return yields a 2% chance...30% expected annualized return yields a 8% chance

- Current Mcap needs to increase by c.28% in order to reach USD 1 trillion (share price of USD 192)
- Analyst consensus target share price for AAPL around USD 170-180. Only one analyst with share price target of USD 202
- Annual share price increases of AAPL over last years around 20% p.a. (max was 38% in 2014). YTD share price performance already 30%
- Monte Carlo (100 paths) only 2-5 simulations above USD 190 share price
- Start with initial 3% to account for potential new product releases by AAPL in Sept 2017

Apple product line-up is facing diminishing advantages over competition.  Their performance is therefore projected to regress to the mean.   Roughly 26% increase from Jul to Jan means an annualized return of 52% -- unlikely.

In saying that current P/E is relatively modest @17, suggesting that there is more room for growth. Still think it is unlikely

That would be another 33% rise on top of the 24% year to date return. A 33% rise would still not put the P/E ratio into astronomical bounds, but Apple would need to announce something that would create massive growth possibilities. It seems like Apple is becoming more of a blue chip these days and paying dividends, which makes rapid, massive growth seemingly unlikely.

This will add resistance to further gains for Apple stock.

It will take a 31% increase in price to hit this mark. Even with a good product release later this year, a bump of this magnitude has never occurred. This is compounded by the fact that the company is much larger than before making a large jump in market cap relatively harder to achieve. That said if Apple is able to develop a revolutionary product, such as cracking the automated car problem, then this market cap would be possible. But such a product is not close and would take sometime to roll out, thus making any move prior to 1 Jan 18 highly unlikely.
As of now (Jun 21), Apple is basically back to where they were in mid April 2017 when the hype began (750-800Bn). That 200+Bn growth has to happen now in 5 months time, a small probability.
They're still good, but are now lacking the innovative spirit that helped fuel their massive growth in the past.

Market cap trend seems very cyclical and the trend line does not at all suggest this will happen. However, I am generally bullish on AAPL and I could imagine in a world in which the debut of the iPhone 8 or whatever other new tech they present in September is sufficiently disruptive as to lead to a huge run up in their stock price.

So, some as yet unforeseen development or announcement could get them there. Still unlikely of course, but maybe slightly higher than it appears today.

Seems very unlikely, although the Trump administration's proposed tax plan, including a tax on cash held overseas might have some effect (if passed and put into effect, a big if). If Apple were essentially forced to repatriate cash to the US some of that could possibly be put in share repurchase programmes, something Carl Icahn for example has lobbied for for years (although he has subsequently reduced his stake). Either way it would take a lot appreciation to reach $1 tr.
Unlikely that AAPL stock will gain 34% from current market cap by January 2018

Must start with an odd of 0. In order for AAPL to have $1 tril. before Jan 1, AAPL must rise by 34% within 6 months from today's price. This kind of sharp rise means a big surprise such as the company is acquired, or AAPL has a new product, or their iPhone8 sells more. The chance for someone to buy the highest cap company in the world is nil. 
Starting bet: 0%
An about 27% increase in market capitalization in less than 1 year for a value stage company is historically improbable.

- innovation: VR, auto, home, IOT
-Everything is overpriced including aapl, amzn but stock hit year highs
-volume = consensus and gives momentum to price direction

In the past year, AAPL has spent much more time time in the "overbought" condition, according to the Williams %R indicator, than in the "oversold" condition.  It is currently oversold, but that is relative to a market that itself is arguably significantly overbought. A new iPhone may kick off another consumer "supercycle" later this year. Or, it could fizzle as consumers, and investors, take a second look at what a disruptive presidency really means. Although I am obviously dubious, I'll keep an eye out for signs of a 35% rise from the June 16th close. Forecasts can be revised.

This would require a roughly 30% increase in stock price over the next six months.
Over the first six months of the year there has been a 24% increase with a high above 30%, but I think the broader market has two headwinds going into the second half of the year:
1) There is a real possibility that corporate tax reform that has been claimed to be part of the reason for the increase in S&P will not happen this year. 
2) There is a roughly 30% possibility of another rate increase from the fed this year which tends to decrease market prices.
sp 500 could crash or go South at any time from now to 1 january 2018
sp 500 could crash at any moment

The main force behind the US stocks in general are foreign buyers running away from mostly sovereign debt crises in their respective domestic markets as well as lack of confidence in the future of EU and other regions. This also applies to the domestic US investors at least those who are allowed by law to invest in to equities instead of bonds. So far I have been talking about the big guys the institutional investors. But wait for the retail chaps to enter the market and this alone could bring the market cap to 1 trillion level. Also any major disaser abroad like say Merkel loosing elections (seems unlikely but look at the Britain's late elections?!) would most certainly deteriorate confidence of investors globaly and thus send their capital to US market. On the flip side historicaly there has been I think only 1 company that reached a market cap of over a trilion $ (adjusted for inflation) i.e. Petro China. Therefore I am starting st 9% and will wait for world events to unfold.

One of my reasons for participating on GJO is for the incentives it creates to learn about new things.  I know absolutely nothing about this kind of question, but since I am an Apple person,  I thought I'd give it a try.  In other words, forecasters, do not follow me on this!

"Yes" would require ca 33% growth in 135 trading days. Raw base rate would be high - more than 50% of days since 2005 have seen such growth. Taken in context: June, just peaked, end of Trump rally, inflation not picking up. Unlikely.

Tech stocks have been shaky for a couple of days, but 1 January is still a fur piece down the road.  They'd still need pretty spectacular numbers for the next few months to make this number.  Stay tuned.
